title: Voyage App for iOS
description: A dive into the business and user assumptions that guided the design of a group hiking app

content.text: Design a service to organize group hiking trips with people in your area—

bullet: Outline user goals / tasks that should be supported in the experience. Consider what constraints, requirements, and assumptions you are making with your design.

Produce a low-fidelity overview of the product or feature (wireframes or sketches are fine) that illustrates how users could get from the start page of this offering to meeting their goals. Design one high-fidelity screen for any individual moment or interaction to showcase visual design capabilities.

Try not to spend more than a few hours. This doesn’t need to be too thorough, we are just looking to learn a bit more about your process, creative thinking, and design skills (e.g. don’t worry about a complete architecture of the application, feel free to just explore one possible flow or task)
Any file format is fine to express your idea (e.g. PDF, keynote, presentation, sketch file, prototype, website, zip, dropbox folder, etc,.)

content.text: Voyage is a business whose mission is to connect people with nature. Voyage is an iOS app that enables people to explore hiking trails and organize group hiking trips. Voyage has three main goals that guide the app's design and functionality—

block.title: Make Nature Easy to Explore
block.description: Voyage wants to be the most reliable resource to learn about nearby trails to prepare for and organize safe group hiking trips.

block.title: Make Nature Safe to Explore
block.description: Voyage wants to make outdoor exploration as safe as possible by documenting important trail details and by working with local governments to maintain local trails.

block.title: Create a Community of Outdoor Enthusiasts
block.description: Voyage represents a community of people that care about nature and each other and believes that an integral component of growing and nurturing a loving community is by enabling users to create new trails, update trail information, and report trail damages and hiker misconduct.

content.text: User needs are defined based on personal hiking experiences and online research about hiker needs and preferences. One important report I found online, 2016 Outdoor Participation Report by Outdoor Foundation, states that some of the reasons why Americans enjoy outdoor activities (including hiking) are to exercise, stay fit, spend time with others, and admire and be close to nature.
Some of the most important assumptions I made to design the Voyage experience include—

block.title: Trail Search Preferences
block.description: Hikers will search nearby trails more frequently than more distant trails. Hikers will most likely value trail length and distance above any other trail factor when selecting a trail to hike.

block.title: Necessary Trail Details
block.description: Hikers value safe hiking experiences and prepare for upcoming hikes by researching the trail's terrain, wildlife presence, weather conditions, trail length, trail history, among other things.

block.title: Group Hiking
block.description: Hikers enjoy hiking in groups to meet new people and stay safe.

content.text: Some of the most important tasks users can accomplish within the Voyage app include—

bullet: Explore trails on a map or list
Search trails by name, region, city, state, and country
Filter trail results by distance to trail, trail length, terrain type, and trail entrance fee
View trail profiles
Create a new hike
Join/leave an upcoming hike
Invite hikers to an upcoming hike
View hiker profiles
File a report for hiker misconduct
Create a new trail and submit for approval
File a report for trail issues/damages
View recent and upcoming hikes
Save favorite trails
Control hike notification settings

content.text: The app has four main sections—Explore, Hikes, Favorites, and Profile. Below is an example of a high-level view and flow of the app. Each mini card represents a different screen—

When launching the app, logged in users are taken to the Explore tab, which displays a map view of the user’s location and nearby trails to provide users with a sense of location and relative position.

Green pins depict trail start points. Tapping a trail pin’s start point displays the trail’s end point, animates the trail’s path, and zooms the map to fit the entire trail into view. Above the trail a card-style gallery appears displaying important trail details to provide users with a glimpse of the displayed trail. Swiping the gallery re-positions the map to display the new trail.
The map view can be toggled to display a list of nearby trails. The list view enables users to search nearby (or filtered) trails by name and trail length versus geographical location.
Trails can be searched by name, region, city, state, and country. Search results prioritize trails over larger regions and user location to make it faster for users to find nearby points of interest.
Filters enable users to control displayed trails. Users can filter results by distance, trail length, trail entrance fee, and trail types.

Pressing a trail card on the map or list view takes users to the trail profile. Trail profiles were designed to provide users with important information that helps users plan and prepare for a safe hiking experience. Trail profiles display trail details and suggested gear equipment prior to listing upcoming hikes to ensure users know what to expect from the hike.

The trail profile features an Upcoming Hikes section that contains a gallery of cards displaying available hikes. Users can sign up for hikes, invite other hikers to an available hike, and create a new hike.
When thinking about a name for the service, I started writing down words that reminded me of nature, connection, community, and exploration—

media.caption: Branding Challenge—60 minutes for naming and designing a simple logo.

content.text: I selected Voyage (French for trip) because it evokes feelings of adventure, courage, and curiosity which are feelings hikers may experience when exploring new trails. I also opted for Voyage because I didn’t want to use a word that was explicitly related to hiking, as I believe the app’s model (after being tested and researched) could be expanded to incorporate other types of outdoor activities like kayaking, rock climbing, and biking.

After selecting the name I started exploring with different logos. I was looking for a logo that reflected a brand that was modern, simple, and contained a small hint of the outdoors. I was looking for a simple logo with very little branding because I wanted to create an experience that focused more on hiking and nature than on the business and the brand.

I did a lot of sketching and exploring and questioning to define the business and user assumptions that guided the app’s design. While some of the conclusions I made weren’t written down, almost all of my thought process and ideation happened on paper. Here are all the sketches and notes I took as I worked through this assignment—

Voyage was designed based on very little hiking experience, minimal online research, and a lot of hiker assumptions. I could keep on exploring and testing out new layouts, but I am aware that they would be based on assumptions and that user testing and feedback are the only way of validating these assumptions to create more focused, guided explorations that are aligned with real user needs.
The whole experience is built on assumptions and nice-to-haves, and I’m aware that turning a project into reality is extremely challenging. Some questions I have about the assumptions I made include—

bullet: How could the service make a profit?
What would the internal report system be like?
How would Voyage validate a new trail submission?
How is a trail’s length measured?
Should hiking groups have a member limit? How do you determine a hike member limit?
Should available hikes be more easily accessible through the Explore tab?
Should trails be reviewed?
Why not display trail lengths on trail pins?
